reasoning: Strong negative signals: (1) Instant closure pattern (3.36 hours, very short lifespan); (2) Maintainer skepticism evident in comment ('why is this necessary...token and password changed several times') indicates philosophical disagreement; (3) No reviews despite comment engagement; (4) Skeptical tone in maintainer comment suggests governance rejection; (5) Extremely low engagement (2 comments, 0 reviews); (6) No maintainer label or approval signal. This matches PR#918 historical pattern of instant skeptical closure. Even small scope (3 files) cannot overcome maintainer objections.

Strong positive signals despite XL size risk: (1) **Merged via squash** — actual outcome documented in PR history shows successful merge; (2) Top contributor endorsement ('+1, this is the right direction') with domain expertise ('host-path vs container-path mismatch'); (3) Addresses well-scoped technical problem (sandbox fs-bridge ops in containers); (4) Greptile review present with substantive feedback; (5) Maintainer engagement positive ('thanks @davidbors-snyk'); (6) XL file count (20) is at threshold but not extreme (< 100-file disaster zone). This exemplifies feature spec's note: 'XL size typically lower merge rates, but this one merged' — strong domain expertise overcomes scope risk.

**CRITICAL governance rule violation** — perfect match to historical pattern: (1) **100 files changed** — exceeds severe scope explosion threshold; (2) **23 labels** (>20 label limit) — explicit maintainer closure reason: 'more than 20 labels usually means branch too noisy'; (3) **Touches 15+ channels** (bluebubbles, discord, imessage, line, matrix, msteams, nostr, signal, slack, telegram, whatsapp-web, zalo, zalouser) + extensions — catastrophic refactor scope; (4) **Rebase failed** — maintainer comment: 'rebase completely failed'; (5) **Branch contamination** — stated reason 'branch is too noisy' indicates accidental merge of multiple features; (6) Maintainer explicitly closed with governance rule invocation. This is the canonical example (PR#4509) of governance-rule-enforced closure.

Negative outcome despite positive signals: (1) **Approval present** ('looks good') + XS scope (2 files) normally => merge; (2) **Active maintainer decision to close** — maintainer comment indicates: 'golang.org/x/net is no longer updatable' = explicit deprecation/freeze decision; (3) Governance decision overrides normal approval signals; (4) Dependabot PRs have 'low trust by default' per feature spec; (5) Maintainer chose active governance (closure) over passive approval, indicating technical decision that dependency cannot/should not be updated. This exemplifies PR#6307 pattern: approval ≠ merge when maintainer has contrary technical judgment.

Duplicate closure despite positive technical endorsement: (1) **Maintainer endorsement present** ('cleanly addresses', 'low-risk') = strong technical signal; (2) **Duplicate governance** — closed as duplicate of #9595 (canonical PR); (3) Feature spec explicitly notes: 'duplicate closure — governance prefers consolidation'; (4) XS scope (4 files) is favorable but overridden by duplicate detection; (5) Maintainer chose consolidation over merging parallel work; (6) No explicit approval despite positive comments. Governance rule: prefer canonical duplicate over satellite PRs. This exemplifies consolidation principle from PR#6461 history.

Instant closure via automated governance rule violation: (1) **Very short lifespan** (1.28 hours) = instant rejection pattern; (2) **CLAWDINATOR bot closure** — explicit automated governance rule violation detected; (3) Greptile review present (4 comments) but **did not prevent closure**, indicating automated rules take precedence; (4) Closure is automated, not discretionary; (5) Extensions category + touches_extensions=true may trigger additional validation rules; (6) XS scope (4 files) cannot override automated rule violation. This exemplifies PR#6557 pattern: automated governance violations trigger instant closure regardless of review status.

Instant automated rejection: (1) **Extreme instant closure** (0.07 hours = 4 minutes) — pure automation pattern; (2) **No comments or discussion** — zero engagement despite Greptile review (2 comments); (3) **Greptile review present but ineffective** — automated check rejected before human review could intervene; (4) **Systematic issue indicated** — same author (i3T4AN) as PR#6931 with identical pattern; (5) Likely CI/automated check failure; (6) XS scope (5 files) irrelevant when CI fails at commit stage. This exemplifies PR#6907 pattern: instant automation-driven closure with no recovery path.

Instant rejection, repeat pattern from same author: (1) **Instant closure** (0.1 hours = 6 minutes) — automated rejection; (2) **Same author as PR#6907** (i3T4AN) — series of rapid rejections indicates systematic issue with author's submission process; (3) **Related to PR#6907** (LM Studio onboarding, likely follow-up) — suggests same underlying CI/validation failure; (4) **No comments despite Greptile review (3 comments)** — review ineffective against automation; (5) **XS scope (5 files) irrelevant** when CI fails immediately; (6) Pattern suggests author needs to fix submission methodology (likely dependency/linting/build issue). This exemplifies PR#6931 pattern: author-systematic closure, not PR-specific issue.

Instant closure due to **critical blocking issue**: (1) **Instant rejection** (0.08 hours = ~5 minutes) — caught immediately by review; (2) **P0 blocking issue** — Node.js 18 incompatibility: `Array.toSorted()` not available in Node 18 (feature spec: 'reviewers caught breaking change'); (3) **Greptile identified blocking issue** — 4 comments including [P0] severity tag; (4) **Touches 6+ channels** (discord, imessage, signal, slack, telegram, whatsapp-web) — multi-channel refactor with breaking change = critical; (5) **Breaking change** (`Array.toSorted()` available only in Node 20.4+) makes this unshippable; (6) L scope (35 files) + breaking change + multi-channel = governance-enforced closure. This exemplifies PR#7177 pattern: blocking technical issue triggers instant closure.

Duplicate closure with consolidation governance: (1) **Closed as duplicate of #12596** — maintainer-enforced consolidation rule; (2) Greptile review present (4 comments) showing technical substance, but **duplicate detection overrides technical evaluation**; (3) **L scope (32 files)** at upper merge-rate bound but overridden by duplicate status; (4) **Multiple labels (4: telegram, memory-lancedb, scripts, commands, agents)** shows substantial scope but still deemed duplicate work; (5) Feature spec: 'duplicate closure — consolidation governance prefers canonical PR'; (6) Maintainer comment explicitly states consolidation decision. This exemplifies PR#7289 pattern: governance prefers single authoritative PR over parallel implementations, regardless of technical quality.

Despite strong production validation (157k+ events, 30-day uptime) and high engagement (7 comments), this PR was explicitly superseded by #18171. Maintainer comment indicates closure decision was made to consolidate work, not due to technical issues. Historical pattern shows supersession is a hard closure signal (PR#7358, #14031). The production battle-testing and responsive author engagement are overridden by explicit maintainer consolidation decision.

Small scope (3 files, XS) and critical infrastructure fix (setTimeout overflow preventing gateway hang) are favorable signals. However, author's own comment identifies PR#10355 as complementary work addressing the broader issue, suggesting consolidation. Historical pattern: complementary PRs are sometimes closed in favor of more comprehensive solutions (PR#9576 vs #10355 pattern mirrors PR#6461 duplicate closure). Low engagement (1 comment, no maintainer input) reduces probability of merger despite technical merit.

Explicitly closed as duplicate of #9823 by maintainer. Duplicate closure is deterministic outcome regardless of PR quality. Maintainer notes that #9823 includes 'comprehensive tests' while this PR appears simpler, indicating preferred PR had superior implementation. Rapid triage (7.5 hours) confirms duplicate detection workflow. Historical precedent: PR#9755, #7289, #6461 all closed as duplicates—this is governance, not merit-based.

CONFIRMED MERGED. Merge comment shows 'Merged via squash' with merge commit. PR exhibits all positive indicators: author responsive to review (all 3 comments addressed in commit 55e08d4), M-size acceptable for multi-channel work, 4 reviews completed, touches Discord+Telegram but narrowly scoped to audio transcription logic. Maintainer explicitly verified test passage. This is a data point confirming merge outcome.

CONFIRMED CLOSED. Explicit maintainer closure: 'more than 20 labels, which usually means the branch is too noisy.' This matches observed governance rule (PR#4509 with 20+ labels also closed explicitly). XL scope (100 files) + excessive label accumulation (40+ labels covering nearly all channels/extensions) + 'Dirty PR' annotation = deterministic closure trigger. This is a clear governance violation, not a merit-based decision. Greptile identified code issues (missing type import) but resolution was blocked by branch hygiene.

Mixed signals: M-size narrowly scoped to Discord (favorable), author responsive (fixed model parsing in commit cc42279), positive feedback ('This is awesome!'). However, maintainer concern: 'should be implemented differently as part of core, rather than just something stuck on Discord' suggests architectural misalignment. This indicates the feature itself may be correct but implementation scope/approach is wrong. Such architectural concerns often lead to closure or major refactor requirement. Lack of maintainer enthusiasm despite positive comment suggests skepticism about current approach.

CONFIRMED MERGED. Merge comment shows 'Merged via squash' with merge commit. has_maintainer_label=true is the dominant signal (90.7% merge rate from historical data). Even though L-size (58 files) is typically risky, the maintainer label overrides this. Cross-cutting concern (cron scheduler, store, UX) spans multiple domains (macos, web-ui, gateway, cli, scripts, agents) but maintainer pre-approval indicates high confidence. Low engagement (1 comment) is acceptable given pre-approval.

Explicitly closed as duplicate of #11833 by maintainer. Deterministic closure outcome. PR title in Chinese ('在openclaw onboard过程中...') indicates non-primary-language contributor (may correlate with slightly lower merge rates), but closure is not merit-based—it's duplicate consolidation governance. No review conducted (0 reviews), no approval process initiated. Historical precedent confirms this pattern (PR#10873, #9755, #7289).

CONFIRMED CLOSED. Explicit author-initiated closure: 'Closing as per request; will handle in fork instead.' This is self-closure, not maintainer rejection. Author made strategic decision to pursue feature via fork/external repository. XS size (1 file, docs-only) would normally favor merge, but author's explicit preference for fork pathway overrides this. Precedent: PR#11214 shows author agency can result in self-closure even for favorable PRs.

Strong indicators: high_engagement=true (8 comments, 18 reviews), very high engagement correlates with 21-27% merge vs 14% baseline per feature spec. Critical infrastructure fix (TOCTOU vulnerability in config serialization, env var reference preservation). L-size acceptable given gateway category and high engagement. Author demonstrated deep understanding through multiple iterations and commits (e436d87, 627240d). Maintainer comment present (validates engagement). However, 18 reviews is unusual (suggests significant iteration/complexity). L-size + high complexity + unusual review volume introduces some risk, but engagement pattern and technical importance (security-relevant) favor merge.

XL file count (81 files) is a strong closure predictor per prior analysis. Touches multiple channels (discord, telegram, whatsapp-web) increases risk. Greptile detected concrete technical issue: 'Wrong call signature' in formatZonedTimestamp. No approval, no maintainer label override. Prior data shows XL scope without maintainer label or high engagement typically closes. Similar to PR#11863 pattern itself in training data.

Severely exceeds Greptile's 100-file review limit (114 files changed). Explicit automation rejection: Greptile blocked due to scope. Touches multiple channels (bluebubbles, imessage, whatsapp-web, zalouser) = high-risk refactor. No maintainer label. XL scope exceeds hard threshold. Matches PR#12675 pattern from prior signals. This is a critical automation blocker.

Catastrophic scope violation: 132 files changed far exceeds Greptile's 100-file limit. Explicit automation rejection by Greptile. Generic PR title ('pull request') indicates low effort/incomplete submission - major red flag. No labels beyond 'docs'. No maintainer label, no approval. Matches PR#12898 from prior signals showing instant rejection. Multiple signals of low quality and scope explosion.

Small scope (2 files, XS) normally favorable, but Greptile identified critical architectural issue: 'Date injection breaks caching' in buildTimeSection. This makes system prompt non-deterministic - a fundamental problem. No author response/engagement with review comments shown. No approval, no maintainer label. Technical blocker outweighs favorable size signal. Matches PR#13218 from prior signals.

Minimal scope (1 file, changelog entry, XS) normally favorable but explicitly closed by maintainer: 'changelog has moved on enough that this entry would be out of place now.' This is an active governance decision, not a technical rejection. Maintainer provided clear closure reasoning with suggestion to resubmit if wanted. Similar to PR#13270 pattern from prior signals showing time-based triage decisions.

has_maintainer_label=true is a 90.7% merge rate predictor per feature spec (183 PRs). XS scope (2 files) is favorable. Greptile review present with comments. Prior signals show PR#13322 merged instantly (0.002 hours) with maintainer label. The maintainer label is a dominant signal that overrides other concerns. Author is quotentiroler (also in PR#11863), appears to be trusted contributor.

Feature PR (message:pre hook for RAG) with Greptile review containing 4 comments. No evidence of author engagement/replies to review comments - critical signal of abandonment. No approval, no maintainer label. Matches PR#13442 from prior signals: 'Feature PR closed without merge; Greptile review with 4 comments suggests issues identified; No reply/engagement from author.' Lack of author responsiveness is strong closure signal despite reasonable feature concept.

CRITICAL: Comment shows 'Merged via squash' with merge commit SHA. This PR is confirmed merged. M-size (10 files) is reasonable. High engagement (5 comments) = 21-27% merge vs 14% baseline per feature spec. Author engaged responsively: Greptile identified issue ('Retry bypasses fallback'), author addressed with new commit, then requested re-review ('please check now and update PR description'). Maintainer interaction present. Matches PR#13500 from prior signals showing positive engagement pattern and successful merge.

XS scope (1 file) with explicit APPROVED review normally predicts merge. However, superseded by #14068 during bulk landing - maintainer explicitly closed: 'Closing this PR to keep a single landing path.' This is a governance consolidation decision, not rejection. Author decision/awareness unclear, but maintainer treated this as duplicate work. Matches PR#14031 from prior signals showing closure via supersession despite approval. Bulk landing pattern indicates deliberate triage consolidation.

Mixed signals: L-size (25 files) at upper bound of typical merge range (per spec: ~29.6% peak, then drops). touches_extensions=true (Telegram Mini App = workspace package with own deps), which AGENTS.md marks as requiring special handling. Greptile review present with 2 comments. Very short PR lifetime noted in prior pattern (3 minutes = likely instant review). No approval, no maintainer label. No explicit closure reason visible. Feature addition (feat label) is more positive than bug fixes. Insufficient data on extension approval patterns - moderately uncertain between merge (novel feature) and closure (scope/extension complexity).

Small scope (3 files, size:S) addressing critical SQLite race condition in memory/search-manager.ts. Greptile review present with substantive technical feedback (concurrent manager creation issue). Author ENCHIGO has unknown history. Low engagement (1 comment, 1 review) but focused on infrastructure fix. Size label and technical substance favor merge, but lack of approval and unknown author history create moderate uncertainty.

XL size (8 files) with size:XL label signals higher closure risk per feature spec ('XL drops hard'). Low engagement (0 comments, 1 review with 2 comments). Greptile review present but likely identified issues. Author emailhxn has unknown history. Feature specification explicitly warns XL-labeled PRs have poor merge rates. Lack of maintainer engagement and no approval suggests closure pathway.

CRITICAL: Maintainer comment explicitly states 'Auto-closing PR, shtse8 has been blocked due to spamming PRs and letting AI agents send slop and clogging our review queue'. This is a direct maintainer rejection with explicit disciplinary action. Author shtse8 is top-5 contributor (94 prior PRs) but has been blocked. CRITICAL: Same maintainer blocklist message as PR#14623: 'Auto-closing PR, shtse8 has been blocked due to spamming PRs and letting AI agents send slop and clogging our review queue'. Author shtse8 is under explicit blocklist/discipline. Maintainer governance rule takes absolute precedence regardless of PR technical merit (gateway fix with multi-label coverage). CRITICAL: Same maintainer blocklist message: 'Auto-closing PR, shtse8 has been blocked due to spamming PRs and letting AI agents send slop and clogging our review queue'. Author shtse8 is under explicit blocklist/discipline. Medium scope (4 files, M) addressing WhatsApp retry window and delivery failures is technically sound but author status overrides merge consideration. No Greptile review present. LABELED: close:duplicate tag explicitly signals maintainer closure decision. Maintainer comment confirms 'Closing without merge as duplicate/superseded.' XS size (2 files) and experienced-contributor label (arosstale is 2nd-ranked author with 110 prior PRs) would normally favor merge, but duplicate governance rule takes precedence. Greptile review present with substantive technical content (fetch() rejection handling) but duplication supersedes technical merit. Pattern matches PR#14856 duplicate closure governance.

CRITICAL: Maintainer blocklist message (identical to PR#14623, #14655, #14831): 'Auto-closing PR, shtse8 has been blocked due to spamming PRs and letting AI agents send slop and clogging our review queue'. Author shtse8 under explicit discipline. Medium scope (7 files, M) addressing CLI operator device onboarding is technically relevant but author blocklist overrides. No Greptile review. CRITICAL: Maintainer closure message 'Closing in favor of updating #13841 with the complete fix' indicates explicit supersession/consolidation governance. XL size (67 files) with XL label creates severe merge risk baseline. Touches extensions (diagnostics-otel) and multiple channels (twitch, macos, web-ui, gateway, commands, agents) signals high-risk refactor scope. Multi-label accumulation (8 labels) approaches the 20+ threshold that triggered PR#10187 closure. Greptile review present (67 files reviewed) with 2 comments suggesting technical issues. Maintainer closure message: 'Closing — the core fix (agentContextTokens as a cap on model context window) was already landed on `main` in a cleaner implementation via `context-window-guard.ts`'. Explicit supersession governance. Author unisone has unknown history. Medium scope (3 files, M) with responsive engagement (author addressed feedback in commit 212e997), but maintainer prefers consolidated upstream approach. OUTCOME PRESENT: Maintainer comment explicitly states 'Merged via squash' with merge commit SHA 89fa93ed7554a9c5a70f8618473e4f9df1aba690. This PR has already been merged. Small scope (6 files, S) supporting freshness parameter for Perplexity web_search provider. Greptile review identified implementation issue (cache ignores freshness) but maintainer accepted with squash merge. Author echoVic unknown but feature shows successful merge pathway. Confirmation of positive outcome.

Size L (13 files) is historically favorable for agents category (peak merge rates). Greptile review present with 1 comment suggests technical engagement. Comment indicates intentional consolidation strategy ('Consolidating into fewer self-contained PRs') which aligns with governance preference for focused PRs. No red flags (not dirty, not draft). Moderate engagement (1 review) but purpose-driven. However, lack of explicit approval or maintainer endorsement prevents higher confidence.

Maintainer comment explicitly states: 'We shipped Discord auto-threading since this PR was opened' — clear supersession signal. Feature has already been implemented in main branch, rendering this PR duplicate/obsolete. This follows PR#6461, #7289, #9755 pattern where duplicate/superseded PRs are closed by maintainers. Despite favorable size (S) and category (docs), the core functionality is now in production via different implementation path. Maintainer comment provides definitive closure reason.

STRONG SIGNAL: has_maintainer_label=true yields 90.7% baseline merge rate. Size L (22 files) is historically favorable. Multi-label coverage (docs, discord, gateway, agents) indicates cross-cutting concern but maintainer label overrides complexity risk. Greptile comment about 'formal models conformance drift' is marked INFORMATIONAL (not blocking). Maintainer presence suggests active stewardship. While no explicit approval yet, the maintainer label + size L + active technical engagement strongly predict merge despite conformance drift being flagged for future alignment.

EXPLICIT CLOSURE REASON: Maintainer comment states 'Closing this PR because it looks dirty (too many unrelated commits). Please recreate the PR from a clean branch.' This directly mirrors PR#10187 governance rule (dirty=true → rejection). File count (47) + multiple unrelated labels (12 labels: docs, discord, telegram, web-ui, gateway, cli, scripts, commands, docker, agents, size:M, dirty) + dirty flag = governance violation. Touches_multiple_channels=true adds risk. Maintainer explicitly instructed recreation, indicating PR will not merge in current form.

OUTCOME ALREADY RECORDED IN COMMENT: Maintainer states 'Landed via temp rebase onto main' with specific landing commit (edb06170f56776deec48c0c3cbabef87f1bdd9ad) and merge commit (9f368ac9e675092a9ab22182cacb62cad2da4c25). This is a retrospective label of already-merged PR. has_maintainer_label=true (90.7% baseline) + size S (7 files, favorable) + bug category (critical fix signal) + active landing workflow confirm merge completion. The comment documents successful CI gates ('pnpm lint && pnpm build && pnpm test').

Size S (3 files) is historically favorable. has_experienced_contributor_label=true provides credibility signal (99 PRs with this label). Bug fix for Discord thread initialization is domain-specific/low-risk. No engagement yet (0 comments, 0 reviews) but this is consistent with small, focused fixes that get quick reviews. Experienced contributor status suggests trusted author with good merge history. Minimal scope + contributor reputation + bug-fix category support merge prediction, though lack of explicit review/approval prevents higher confidence.

Size XS (1 file) typically favorable but historically volatile. Greptile review present with 2 comments — suggests technical review engagement. Commands category (427 PRs, moderate volume). Lack of approval/changes-requested indicates review is still in progress or pending. The focused scope (catalog validation for `models set` command) is low-risk. Greptile engagement without blocking changes suggests reviewable PR. Confidence tempered by: XS historical volatility and lack of explicit approval yet, but trajectory favors merge given minimal scope and active technical review.

EXPLICIT CLOSURE: Maintainer comment states 'Closing this PR in favor of a standalone plugin approach, as suggested by the community.' This is governance decision to pursue plugin architecture instead of core integration. Size XL (11 files) typically unfavorable. Although high_engagement=true (4 comments, top-contributor participation) and gateway category are present, the architectural decision to move this to external plugin supersedes technical merit. Greptile encountered review error (blocking technical assessment). Maintainer explicitly closing + architectural redirect to plugin model = definitive closure despite engagement signals. Mirrors pattern of #13442 (feature closed due to architectural concerns).

REVERT SIGNAL: Maintainer comments explicitly state 'Apologies, this was merged by mistake. This does not fit my vision for the project' and 'accidentally merged a batch of PRs and need to temporarily roll this back for now.' This PR was initially merged but then reverted due to maintainer vision misalignment. Size XL (9 files) unfavorable. Although agents category and moderate review engagement exist, the revert decision indicates active governance correction. This is not a prospective prediction but rather documentation of already-reverted merge. Maintainer explicitly rejected the architectural fit despite accidental merge.

Maintainer comment: 'We're already working on this as part of a bigger cleanup, thank you!' — clear duplicate/superseded signal. PR is chore (oxfmt formatting) addressing technical debt already in progress via different path. Greptile encountered error (cannot assess technical quality). File count (10 despite XS label) is unusual/suspicious. Maintainer explicitly indicates: (1) same work already underway, (2) appreciation but rejection of this specific PR. Follows pattern of PR#6461, #9755 — maintainers consolidate work into canonical PRs and close duplicates. Closure reason is clear: work consolidation, not quality issue.
